Alert: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy Header Missing or Invalid
Risk: Low (2 confidence)
Instances: 3
CWE: 693
Description: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header is a response header that prevents a document from loading any cross-origin resources that don't explicitly grant the document permission (using CORP or CORS).
Solution: Ensure that the application/web server sets the Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header appropriately, and that it sets the Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header to 'require-corp' for documents.If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that supports the Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy header (https://caniuse.com/mdn-http_headers_cross-origin-embedder-policy).

Alert: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
Risk: Low (1 confidence)
Instances: 1
CWE: 497
Description: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server. - Unix
Solution: Manually confirm that the timestamp data is not sensitive, and that the data cannot be aggregated to disclose exploitable patterns.

Alert: Modern Web Application
Risk: Informational (2 confidence)

Description: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.
Solution: This is an informational alert and so no changes are required.

Alert: Storable and Cacheable Content
Risk: Informational (2 confidence)
Instances: 5
CWE: 524
Description: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching
Solution: Validate that the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information. If it does, consider the use of the following HTTP response headers, to limit, or prevent the content being stored and retrieved from the cache by another user:Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, privatePragma: no-cacheExpires: 0This configuration directs both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1 compliant caching servers to not store the response, and to not retrieve the response (without validation)

Alert: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
Risk: Informational (1 confidence)
Instances: 3
CWE: 615
Description: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker.
Solution: Remove all comments that return information that may help an attacker and fix any underlying problems they refer to.

Alert: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
Risk: Low (2 confidence)
Instances: 5
CWE: 693
Description: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.
Solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Permissions-Policy header.
